706257f-b.text:
Pierrepont Street, south side, west from No. 20 at left foreground. The building with the flag displayed is No 10. and know as the Chittendon House. At the left background, is part of the Pierrepont Mansion facing and know as No. 1 Pierrepont Place.

May 1925
Eugene L. Armbrauter Collection.

2)A continuation of No. 1 showing at left background, the complete view of the Pierrepont Mansion facing Pierrepont Place. At left is partial view of No. 6 Pierrepont Street.

April 1925
Eugene L. Armbrauter Collection.
706257f-b.folder: Pierrepont Street & Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, NY

706252f-b.text:
Pierrepont Place, east side, from Pierrepont Street; in the background, to Montague Street in the foreground. The bridge is a passenger crossing Over Montague Street, which street starts down
at the East River.
April 7, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same; showing the west side of Pierrepont Place.
April 7, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, as seen from Montague Street which here slopes downwards to the East River. The upper level is used solely by pedestrians.
April 7, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

703721f-a.title: Brooklyn: Columbia Heights - Pierrepont Street
703721f-a.text:
196-214 Columbia Heights, west side, north of Pierrepont Street, show. ing No. 204 (5-story building) to the left of which is the former hone of
DDeacon White.(No. 210).
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
703721f-a.folder: Columbia Heights & Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, NY

703722f-a.title: Brooklyn: Columbia Heights - Pierrepont Street
703722f-a.text:
201 Columbia Heights, at the N.E. corner of Pierrepont Street, showing the home of Seth Low who was born at No. 165 (now 189) Washington Street, on January 18, 1850.  He was elected Mayor of Brooklyn in 1881. This house owned by James Humphreys, a republican, who was a member of Congress during the Civil War, was sold to Mr.Seth Low who modernized it. The house
was razed in May 1924.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
703722f-a.folder: Columbia Heights & Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, NY

703723f-b.title: Brooklyn: Columbia Heights - Pierrepont Street
703723f-b.text:
(1)
220-222 Columbia Heights, at the N.W. corner of Columbia Heights and Pierrepont Street. The house at the left was that of Peter C. Cornell and later that of David H. Leggett. The house at the right (No. 220) belonged to John Bullet, and at one time was occupied by Henry K. Shelton.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2) The same, showing a further view north.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
703723f-b.folder: Columbia Heights & Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, NY

706249f-a.text:
1-3 Pierrepont Place, west side, south from Pierrepont to Montague Streets. The pedestrians bridge in the background, crosses Montague Street, which at this point, slopes down to the East River. Also seen is 2-10 Montague Terrace, west side, south from Montague to Remsen Streets. ( Montague Terrace, is really a continuation of Pierrepont Placel.
June 1926.
Brown Brothers.
706249f-a.folder: Pierrepont Place & Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, NY

1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

June 11, 1927.

706256f-a.text:
6 Pierrepont Street, south side, east of Pierrepont Place, showing the home of John F. James, a banker, who in 1861 became a partner in the real estate firm of Wyckoff and Little, whose offices are at No. 189 Montague Street.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
